awd_titl_txt: From Dwarf Galaxies to Neutrino Oscillations: A Cosmic Connection Beyond the Standard Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Daniel Boyanovsky at the University of Pittsburgh. 

The last two decades have been an exhilarating journey of discovery in particle physics and cosmology.  In this project, Professor Boyanovsky will continue his interdisciplinary research in cosmology and particle physics.  He will focus on developing a deeper understanding of quantum processes and correlations during the inflationary stage in the early Universe, and study their potential observability in forthcoming measurements.  He will also undertake an assessment of neutrinos in extensions beyond the Standard Model as possible dark matter candidates.

This project is also likely to have a broader interdisciplinary impact, as Professor Boyanovsky's research involves implementing and merging methods from different branches of physics to study aspects of quantum correlations and entanglement and possible observational consequences both in cosmology and in neutrino physics.  He will also mentor a graduate student who will work with him on the goals of this project, and train this graduate student to perform cutting-edge research in particle physics and cosmology.

por.por_cntn:
The breakthrough discoveries that 80% of the matter in the Universe is ``Dark'', that the Universal expansion is accelerating, thus calling for a new form of energy, ``Dark Energy'',  and the recent discovery of the long sought Higgs particle pose challenging and urgent questions on the current paradigm: the ``Standard Model''. Dark Matter and Dark Energy cannot be explained within this paradigm and the discovery of the Higgs boson along with the discovery that neutrinos feature mass and mix among the various flavors invite us to search for physics beyond the Standard Model. Neutrino masses and mixing are the first and uncontroversial hint of physics beyond the Standard Model. If new species of neutrinos are discovered, they can be suitable candidates to explain Dark Matter. Precise observations of the cosmic microwave background radiation, the relic radiation from the Big Bang, supports the theoretical ideas that the early stages of the Universe after the Big Bang are explained by ``inflation'' a period of rapid expansion of the Universe. The small temperature variations detected in this relic radiation are interpreted as originating from quantum fluctuations born during this period of accelerated expansion and in turn are the seeds that ultimately lead to the formation of Galaxies. This fascinating theoretical concept is supported by precise current observations with satellites and earth-bound telescopes: the Universe that we see today, populated by galaxies and stars was borne out of small quantum wiggles in space-time produced during a brief early inflationary phase!.These exhilarating discoveries, bring, in turn challenging questions, whose answers require a fundamental assessment of the various mechanisms that produce these quantum fluctuations. On the issue of Dark Matter, despite an intense effort over the last two decades to detect directly a popular particle expected beyond the Standard Model, the nature of the Dark Matter particle candidate remains elusive. Our program focuses on providing a fundamental and sound framework to assess these challenging questions. We seek to understand at a deeper level the nature of the ``quantum seeds'' that originate during the inflationary stage and extract observational consequences that could help to discriminate among the various inflation models. On the Dark Matter front, our program seeks to assess reliably the possibility that new generation of more massive neutrinos could be the long sought Dark Matter candidate. Our approach departs from the traditional route of inquiry in that we borrow methods, concepts and tools from other branches of physics and bring them to bear on the ultimate questions of Dark Matter and Dark Energy. Our program has been and continuous to be interdisciplinary. Many of the methods that we implement are borrowed and adapted from   completely different fields: quantum computing and quantum optics, in turn we were able to contribute to these fields. Therefore our program represents a cross fertilization of fields and ideas that seeks to answer some of the more fundamental questions posed by mankind with respect to our Universe. The intellectual merit of this endeavor is clearly undisputable as the program seeks answers to some of the most profound, timely and challenging  questions in modern science. The interdisciplinary aspect of our program  provides opportunities for a broader impact across fields, and already some of the results of the program have made an impact in other disciplines. We expect that as we continue to make progress, our contributions will transcend fields and continue making an impact across disciplines as it continues to elucidate the fundamental questions of Dark Matter and Dark Energy.
